q: Which standard is related to Metadata exchange?
options: Extensible Markup Language (XML) Schema Definition (XSD)
JavaScript Object Notation (JSON)
Common Warehouse Metamodel (CWM) / XML Metadata Interchange (XMI)
Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP)
Representational State Transfer (REST)
expl: CWM/XMI/ISO 11179 are metadata standards.

q: Impact Analysis helps to:
options: Determine the root cause of a data quality failure in a source system
Determine the downstream effects of changing a data element or structure
Calculate the financial return on investment (ROI) for a data governance program
Identify the optimal hardware configuration for a new database server
Assess the risk of a potential data breach before it occurs
expl: Lineage allows you to see what breaks if you change a column.

q: What is a 'Metamodel'?
options: A data model that describes the structure and rules of the metadata repository itself
A consolidated enterprise logical data model that spans all business units
A conceptual framework used to design the physical data warehouse architecture
A predictive machine learning model used to automatically classify new data assets
A standardized template used for documenting business glossaries
expl: The schema that defines how metadata is stored.

q: Effective Metadata Management enables:
options: Self-service data access and increased trust in data assets
The complete elimination of all data silos across the enterprise
Automated, real-time correction of all data quality errors
The replacement of traditional data warehouses with data lakes
A reduction in the need for dedicated data stewards
expl: Context = Trust. Users can find and understand data.

q: Unstructured data accounts for roughly what % of enterprise data?
options: Nearly 100%
expl: The '80/20 rule' applies: ~80% of data is unstructured.

q: A 'Taxonomy' is:
options: A flat, uncontrolled vocabulary of tags created by end-users
A hierarchical classification of terms representing parent-child relationships
A legal framework governing the taxation of digital assets
A physical index structure used to optimize database queries
A set of rules defining how data should be archived
expl: Hierarchy/Tree structure used for classification.

q: eDiscovery refers to:
options: The automated profiling of new data sources added to a data lake
The process of identifying, preserving, and collecting electronic data for legal evidence
The use of artificial intelligence to uncover hidden patterns in customer behavior
The process of mapping legacy data structures to a new target schema
The proactive scanning of networks for unauthorized data exfiltration
expl: Legal search for electronic records.

q: What does OCR stand for?
options: Optical Character Recognition
Object Content Repository
Online Customer Record
Operational Control Requirement
Organizational Change Readiness
expl: Technology to convert images of text into machine-encoded text.

q: Records Management is primarily concerned with:
options: Optimizing the performance of the enterprise data warehouse
The lifecycle management (retention and disposal) of evidence and official records
The creation and distribution of marketing collateral
The technical administration of document management software
The real-time processing of transactional data streams
expl: Managing the legal lifecycle and retention schedules of records.

q: A 'Folksonomy' is created by:
options: A centralized committee of subject matter experts and taxonomists
Users collaboratively tagging content (crowdsourced or social tagging)
Mandatory industry regulations and compliance standards
Automated natural language processing (NLP) algorithms
The database administrators who design the physical schema
expl: Social classification (e.g., hashtags).

q: Metadata embedded directly within a file (like EXIF data in a photograph) is known as:
options: Embedded Metadata
External Metadata
System Metadata
Business Metadata
Administrative Metadata
expl: Stored inside the file header itself.

q: Which lifecycle phase involves the legally mandated destruction of records?
options: Creation and Receipt
Active Use and Maintenance
Disposal / Disposition
Inactive Storage and Archival
Classification and Indexing
expl: Secure destruction according to retention schedules.

q: GDPR's 'Right to Explanation' concerns:
options: Understanding the logic and consequences of an automated decision (e.g., AI) made about a person
The requirement for companies to publish their data retention schedules publicly
The right of a user to know the physical location of the servers storing their data
The obligation to disclose the financial cost of processing a data subject access request
The requirement to explain the technical architecture of the data warehouse to regulators
expl: Transparency in Algorithmic decision making.

q: Bias in AI models often stems from:
options: Syntax errors in the underlying programming code
Biased training data that reflects historical prejudices or systemic inequalities
Insufficient processing power during the model training phase
The use of open-source machine learning libraries instead of proprietary ones
Overly strict data security protocols that limit access to the full dataset
expl: Bias In = Bias Out. Models learn historical prejudices.

q: Simpson's Paradox illustrates a situation where:
options: Data quality improves as the volume of data increases
Aggregated data can hide or reverse trends that are clearly present in the underlying subgroups
Increasing data security inevitably decreases data availability
The cost of storing data eventually exceeds the value derived from it
Anonymized data can always be re-identified using external datasets
expl: Statistical paradox where aggregation hides the truth.

q: Data Ethics is distinct from Data Privacy because:
options: Privacy focuses on legal compliance ('Can we?'), while Ethics focuses on moral obligation ('Should we?')
Privacy applies only to structured data, while Ethics applies to unstructured data
Privacy is a concern only in Europe (GDPR), while Ethics is a global standard
Ethics is a technical discipline, while Privacy is a business discipline
Ethics is entirely optional, whereas Privacy is strictly mandatory
expl: Compliance asks 'Can we?'; Ethics asks 'Should we?'.

q: What is 'Consent' in the context of data ethics and privacy?
options: The automatic collection of data based on a user's continued use of a service
Informed, voluntary, and explicit agreement by the data subject to specific data processing activities
The legal right of a company to purchase data from a third-party broker
The assumption of permission based on the data being publicly available on the internet
The agreement between two companies to share customer data for marketing purposes
expl: Informed consent is a cornerstone of ethical data collection.

q: De-identification is the process of:
options: Removing or obfuscating Personally Identifiable Information (PII) to protect privacy
Deleting inactive user accounts from the system after a specified period
Assigning unique surrogate keys to replace natural business keys
Verifying a user's identity through multi-factor authentication
Tracking and logging all user activity within a database
expl: Stripping identifiers to protect privacy.

q: The '3 Vs' defining Big Data are:
options: Value, Vision, and Velocity
Volume, Velocity, and Variety
Virtualization, Visualization, and Validation
Verification, Validation, and Value
Volatility, Vulnerability, and Volume
expl: Size (Volume), Speed (Velocity), Shape (Variety).

q: Schema-on-Read means:
options: The data structure is strictly defined and enforced before data is loaded into the repository
The structure and meaning are applied only when the data is queried or analyzed
The data is completely unstructured and cannot be queried using SQL
The data is stored in a read-only format to prevent unauthorized modifications
The schema is automatically deleted immediately after the data is read
expl: Data Lake characteristic. Load raw, define structure later.

q: Supervised Learning in Machine Learning relies on:
options: Labeled training data containing known input-output pairs
Unlabeled data where the algorithm must discover hidden patterns independently
Randomly generated noise to test the robustness of the model
A predefined set of rigid, rule-based programming logic
Continuous feedback from a human operator during every prediction
expl: Supervised = Teaching with examples (Labels). Unsupervised = Finding patterns.

q: Data Wrangling (or Munging) is best described as:
options: The process of securing data centers against physical threats
Cleaning, transforming, and mapping raw data into a usable format for downstream analysis
The automated archiving of historical data to cheaper storage tiers
The process of designing interactive dashboards for executive reporting
Compressing large datasets to reduce network transmission times
expl: Data Munging/Preparation for analytics.

q: In data visualization, 'Chart Junk' refers to:
options: Data points that are statistically insignificant outliers
Unnecessary visual elements (e.g., 3D effects, heavy gridlines) that distract from the core message
The use of pie charts, which are universally discouraged by data scientists
A dashboard that contains too many different types of charts
Visualizations that fail to include proper axis labels and legends
expl: Visual noise/clutter in dataviz.

q: MapReduce is a programming model designed for:
options: Processing small, highly structured datasets in memory
Distributed processing of large datasets across clusters of commodity hardware
Rendering complex geographic maps and spatial data
Reducing the physical storage footprint of image and video files
Executing single-threaded, sequential batch jobs
expl: Hadoop processing model (Map = split, Reduce = aggregate).

q: A Data Scientist primarily focuses on:
options: Installing, configuring, and tuning database management systems
Predictive modeling, statistical analysis, and developing advanced machine learning algorithms
Designing the physical schema for the enterprise data warehouse
Managing the daily execution of ETL batch jobs
Creating standard operational reports for business users
expl: Advanced analytics vs Data Engineering or DBA work.

q: Sentiment Analysis is an application of:
options: Natural Language Processing (NLP)
Computer Vision and Image Recognition
Structured SQL Querying and Aggregation
Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processing
Database Indexing and Query Optimization
expl: Analyzing text to determine emotion/intent.
